{{Infobox person |name=Nataline Sarkisyan |image=Natalinesarkisyan.jpg |caption= |birth_name=Nataline Mary Sarkisyan |birth_date={{birth date|1990|7|10}} |birth_place=[[Los Angeles, California]], U.S. |death_date={{death date and age|2007|12|20|1990|7|10}} |death_place=Los Angeles, California, U.S. |occupation=Student |parents=Krikor (also spelled Grigor) and Hilda Sarkisyan |nationality= }} '''Nataline Mary Sarkisyan''' ; July 10, 1990 – December 20, 2007) was an American teenager with recurrent [[leukemia]]. Her case became part of the [[health care reform debate in the United States]] in 2007 when [[Cigna HealthCare]] denied coverage for a [[liver transplant]] operation. The company later reversed its decision after a great deal of media attention to her story, but Sarkisyan died hours later.<ref name="book1">Flower, Joe. [https://books.google.com/books?id=rtzq6syWSm0C&pg=PA193#v=onepage&q&f=false Healthcare Beyond Reform: Doing It Right for Half the Cost], p. 193</ref><ref name="2011-nyt-1">Chen, Pauline W. (6 January 2011). [https://www.nytimes.com/2011/01/06/health/views/06chen.html?pagewanted=all&_r=0 When Insurers Put Profits Between Doctor and Patient], ''[[The New York Times]]''</ref>
==Background== Sarkisyan was diagnosed with leukemia at age 14. She was covered under her father's health insurance, through his employer, Mercedez-Benz. The employer plan was administered by Cigna HealthCare.<ref>[https://www.mercurynews.com/2007/12/28/hundreds-attend-funeral-for-southern-california-teen-who-died-during-transplant-delay/ Hundreds attend funeral for Southern California teen who died during transplant delay], By Associated Press and Noaki Schwartz, Mercury News, December 28, 2007</ref> During her treatment for leukemia, her liver deteriorated.
Sarkisyan's doctors at the UCLA Medical Center told the family and Cigna that they recommended a [[liver transplant]], and patients in similar circumstances have a six-month survival rate of 65%. Different doctors gave different estimates of the likelihood of success. Dr. John Roberts, chief of the transplant service at [[UC San Francisco]] (not the transplant center treating Sarkisyan), said{{When|date=July 2009}} that his center generally does not accept a patient without a 50% or greater five year survival rate. Dr. Goran Klintmalm, chief of the Baylor Regional Transplant Institute in [[Dallas]], said {{When|date=July 2009}} this particular operation was a "very high-risk transplant," but that he would consider the same operation on a similar patient.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.latimes.com/business/la-fi-transplant22dec22,1,3777077.story?coll=la-headlines-business&track=crosspromo |title=Tough calls in transplant case - Los Angeles Times |publisher=Latimes.com |date=2007-12-22 |accessdate=2012-10-08}}</ref> On December 11, 2007, Cigna rejected the request for coverage for the liver transplant. Sarkisyan's doctors at UCLA, including the head of its transplant unit, wrote a letter to protest that the treatment proposed was neither experimental nor unproven and called on Cigna to urgently review its decision.
Cigna HealthCare refused to pay for treatment by citing policy provisions which do not cover services considered experimental, investigational and/or unproven to be safe and/or effective for the patient.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cigna.com/customer_care/healthcare_professional/coverage_positions/medical/mm_0355_coveragepositioncriteria_liver_transplant_cadaveric_donor.pdf|title=CIGNA document|publisher=Cigna.com|accessdate=2012-10-08}}</ref> Cigna said that it had no financial stake in the decision because it only administered the insurance plan and would not bear the cost of any operation. The cost of a liver transplant and one year of follow-up care was $450,000 in 2005. UCLA declined two livers while waiting for insurance approval from Cigna. Ms. Sarkisyan's family was also informed that they could proceed with the transplant if they could make a down-payment of $75,000.
Among the groups who publicly spoke out against Cigna's decision was the [[California Nurses Association/National Nurses Organizing Committee]].<ref name="nurse1">Prosono, Marvin. [https://books.google.com/books?id=L5BHiqeA-dMC&pg=PA273#v=onepage&q&f=false 'Bystander Sociology' and the Sonderbehandlung of the Social] in ''The Shape of Sociology for the 21st Century: Tradition and Renewal'', at p. 273 (2010)</ref>
After public media attention grew, Cigna reversed its decision, but offered to pay for the transplant itself when it made the exception to the policy.<ref>Vanessa Fuhrmans & Laura Meckler; [https://web.archive.org/web/20080108022106/http://online.wsj.com/article/SB119967240787671395.html "A Medical Case Becomes Political"]; ''The Wall Street Journal'' 2008-01-07, p. A1</ref> Cigna's reversal of its policy, offering to pay for the transplant, came just hours before Sarkisyan's death.<ref name="guard1">Pilkington, Ed (21 December 2007). [https://www.theguardian.com/world/2007/dec/22/usa.international Insurer's U-turn too late to save life of transplant teenager], ''[[The Guardian]]''</ref>
==Aftermath==
Sarkisyan's family spoke out at a [[New Hampshire]] rally in support of Senator John Edwards' presidential campaign on January 6, 2008 based on his advocacy of reforming and overhauling the US health care system.<ref>{{cite web|author=TomP |url=http://www.dailykos.com/storyonly/2008/1/6/103755/8442 |title=Update IV (Video of Sarkisyans at Rally): Family of Nataline Sarkisyan To Join Edwards Today |publisher=Daily Kos |date=2008-01-06 |accessdate=2012-10-08}}</ref><ref>Wendell Potter [http://wendellpotter.com/deadlyspin/ Deadly Spin: An insurance company insider speaks out how corporate PR is killing health care and deceiving Americans], Bloomsbury Press, November, 2010, chapters 8-9</ref><ref name="phill1">Burling, Stracey (13 January 2008). [http://articles.philly.com/2008-01-13/business/25254025_1_health-insurance-nataline-sarkisyan-ethicists When a health insurer says it won't pay Ethicists and economists say a 17-year-old girl's case points up complex questions on rationing resources], ''[[Philadelphia Inquirer]]''</ref>
==Lawsuit== Sarkisyan's family retained attorney [[Mark Geragos]] to sue Cigna, and requested that [[Los Angeles County District Attorney]] [[Steve Cooley]] file murder charges against the insurer.<ref name="crim1">(22 December 2007). [http://abcnews.go.com/GMA/story?id=4043101&page=1%20Attorney%20Wants%20Criminal%20Charges%20Against%20Insurer Attorney Wants Criminal Charges Against Insurer ], ''ABC News''</ref><ref name="abc2">Hernandez, Miriam (21 December 2007). [http://abclocal.go.com/kabc/story?section=news/local&id=5849791 Teen's family plans to sue health insurer], ''KABC-TV''</ref><ref name="Annual fashion show keeps Nataline Sarkisyan's story alive">{{cite news|last=Abram|first=Susan|title=Annual fashion show keeps Nataline Sarkisyan's story alive|url=http://www.dailynews.com/ci_21048646/annual-fashion-show-keeps-nataline-sarkisyans-story-alive|accessdate=23 January 2013|newspaper=Daily News Los Angeles|date=07/10/2012}}</ref><ref name="usatoday1">(21 December 2007). [http://usatoday30.usatoday.com/news/health/2007-12-21-497425926_x.htm Lawsuit promised in transplant case], ''[[USA Today]]''</ref> The case was thrown out due to a ''Pilot Life Ins. Co. v. Dedeaux'', 1987 U.S. Supreme Court ruling shielding employer-paid healthcare plans from damages over their coverage decisions.<ref name="latimes">{{cite web|author=Lisa Girion |url=http://articles.latimes.com/2009/oct/08/business/fi-cigna8 |title=Insurer's agreement to cover surgery comes too late - Los Angeles Times |publisher=Articles.latimes.com |date=2009-10-18 |accessdate=2012-10-08}}</ref>

{{Infobox government agency |agency_name = Department of Health |type = Department |nativename = ''Kagawaran ng Kalusugan'' |nativename_a = |nativename_r = |logo = |logo_width = |logo_caption = |motto = [[:la:Floreat Salubritas Populi|Floreat Salubritas Populi]], Promotion of health for the people |seal = Department of Health (DOH) PHL.svg |seal_width = |seal_caption = |picture = |picture_width = |picture_caption = |formed = |preceding1 = |preceding2 = |dissolved = |superseding = |jurisdiction = |headquarters = San Lazaro Compound, [[Rizal Avenue]], [[Santa Cruz, Manila|Santa Cruz]], [[Manila]] |coordinates = {{coord|14|36|55.95|N|120|58|54.99|E|type:landmark|display=inline}} |employees = |budget = {{Philippine peso|107.3 Billion}} (2018)<ref>{{cite web|title=GAA 2018|url=https://www.rappler.com/move-ph/issues/budget-watch/191632-government-office-2018-national-budget-overview|work=DBM|accessdate=24 January 2018}}</ref> |minister1_name = |minister1_pfo = |minister2_name = |minister2_pfo = |chief1_name = [[Francisco Duque]] |chief1_position = Secretary |chief2_name = |chief2_position = |agency_type = |parent_agency = |child1_agency = |child2_agency = |keydocument1= |website = {{URL|www.doh.gov.ph}} |footnotes = |map = |map_width = |map_caption = }} The Philippine '''Department of Health''' (abbreviated as '''DOH'''; {{lang-fil|Kagawaran ng Kalusugan}}) is the [[Executive Departments of the Philippines|executive department]] of the [[Politics of the Philippines|Philippine government]] responsible for ensuring access to basic [[public health]] services by all Filipinos through the provision of quality [[health care]] and the regulation of all health services and products. It is the government's over-all technical authority on health.<ref>{{cite web|title=DOH Profile|url=http://www.doh.gov.ph/node/97.html|accessdate=17 January 2013}}</ref> It has its headquarters at the San Lazaro Compound, along [[Rizal Avenue]] in [[Manila]].
The department is led by the [[Secretary of Health (Philippines)|Secretary of Health]], nominated by the [[President of the Philippines]] and confirmed by the [[Commission on Appointments (Philippines)|Commission on Appointments]]. The Secretary is a member of the [[Cabinet of the Philippines|Cabinet]]. The current Secretary of Health is [[Francisco Duque]].
==History== Americans assembled a military Board of Health on September 10, 1898, with its formal organization on September 29. Upon its creation, Dr. [[Frank S. Bourns]] is assigned as president while Dr. C. L. Mullins is assigned as assistant surgeon.<ref>{{cite book|title=Seventh Annual Report of the Philippine Commission Part 2|date=1907|publisher=Government Printing Office|location=Washington|page=58}}</ref> The purpose of this Board of Health was to care for injured American troops but as the hostilities between Filipinos and Americans waned in 1901, a civilian Board of Health was now deemed appropriate with Dr. [[L. M. Maus]] as the first health commissioner.
In the early 1900s, 200,222 lives including 66,000 children were lost; three percent of the population was decimated in the worst epidemic in Philippine health history. In view of this, the Americans organized and erected several institutions, including the Bureau of Governmental Laboratories, which was built in 1901 for medical research and vaccine production.
The Americans, led by [[Dean Worcester]] built the [[University of the Philippines College of Medicine|UP College of Medicine and Surgery]] in 1905, with [[Johns Hopkins University]] serving as a blueprint, at the time, one of the best medical schools in the world. By 1909, nursing instruction was also begun at the [[Philippine Normal University|Philippine Normal School]]. In terms of public health, the Americans improved on the sewer system and provided a safer water supply.
In 1915, the Bureau of Health was reorganized and renamed into the Philippine Health Service. During the succeeding years leadership and a number of health institutions were already being given to Filipinos, in accordance with the Organic Act of 1916. On January 1, 1919, Dr. Vicente De Jesus became the first Filipino to head the Health portfolio.
In 1933, after a reorganization, the Philippine Health Service reverted to being known as the Bureau of Health. It was during this time that it pursued its official journal, ''The Health Messenger'' and established Community Health and Social Centers, precursors to today's [[Barangay Health Center]]s.
By 1936, as Governor-General Frank Murphy was assuming the post of United States [[High Commissioner]], he would remark that the Philippines led all oriental countries in terms of health status.<ref>[http://www.doh.gov.ph/sphh/1930.htm 1930's: Passing the Torch]</ref>
When the [[Commonwealth of the Philippines]] was inaugurated, Dr. [[Jose Fabella]] was named chief of the Bureau of Health. In 1936, Dr. Fabella reviewed the Bureau of Health’s organization and made an inventory of its existing facilities, which consisted of 11 community and social health centers, 38 hospitals, 215 puericulture centers, 374 sanitary divisions, 1,535 dispensaries and 72 laboratories.
In the 1940s, the Bureau of Health was reorganized into the Department of Health and Public Welfare, still under Fabella. During this time, the major priorities of the agency were [[tuberculosis]], [[malnutrition]], [[malaria]], [[leprosy]], gastrointestinal disease, and the high infant [[mortality rate]].
When the Japanese occupied the Philippines, they dissolved the National Government and replaced it with the Central Administrative Organization of the [[Imperial Japanese Army|Japanese Army]]. Health was relegated to the Department of Education, Health and Public Welfare under Commissioner [[Claro M. Recto]].
In 1944, [[President of the Philippines|President]] [[Manuel Roxas]] signed Executive Order (E.O.) No. 94 into law, calling for the creation of the Department of Health. Dr. Antonio C. Villarama as appointed Secretary. A new Bureau of Hospitals and a Bureau of Quarantine was created under DOH. Under E.O. 94, the Institute of Nutrition was created in 1948 to coordinate various nutrition activities of the different agencies.
On February 20, 1958, Executive Order 288 provided for the reorganization of the Department of Health. This entailed a partial decentralization of powers and created eight Regional Health Offices. Under this setup, the Secretary of Health passed on some of responsibilities to the regional offices and directors.
One of the priorities of the [[Ferdinand E. Marcos|Marcos]] administration was health maintenance. From 1975 to the mid-eighties, four specialty hospitals were built in succession. The first three institutions were spearheaded by [[First Lady of the Philippines|First Lady]] [[Imelda Marcos]]. The [[Philippine Heart Center]] was established on February 14, 1975 with Dr. Avelino Aventura as director. Second, the Philippine Children’s Medical Center was built in 1979. Then in 1983, the National Kidney and Transplant Institute was set up. This was soon followed by the [[Lung Center of the Philippines]], which was constructed under the guidance of Health Minister Dr. [[Enrique Garcia]].
With a shift to a parliamentary form of government, the Department of Health was transformed into the Ministry of Health on June 2, 1978 with Dr. [[Clemente S. Gatmaitan]] as the first health minister. On April 13, 1987, the Department of Health was created from the previous Ministry of Health with Dr. [[Alfredo R. A. Bengzon]] as secretary of health.
==List of Secretaries of Health== {{main|Secretary of Health (Philippines)}}
==Organizational Structure== At present, the Department is headed by the [[Secretary of Health (Philippines)|Secretary of Health]], with five undersecretaries and seven assistant secretaries. *Undersecretary for Health Regulation *Undersecretary for Field Implementation and Management *Undersecretary for Health Service Development *Undersecretary for Technical Services *Undersecretary for Policy and Health Systems *Undersecretary for Administration, Finance and Procurement *Assistant Secretary for Technical Services *Assistant Secretary for Administration, Finance and Procurement *Assistant Secretary for Special Concerns *Assistant Secretary for Health Regulation *Assistant Secretary for Field Implementation and Management *Assistant Secretary for Mindanao Cluster
===Bureaus=== The DOH is composed of bureaus, namely: *Epidemiology Bureau (formerly National Epidemiology Center) *Bureau of Health Devices and Technology *Bureau of Health Facilities and Services *Bureau of International Health Cooperation *Bureau of Local Health Systems Development *Bureau of Quarantine *Disease Prevention and Control Bureau (formerly National Center for Disease Prevention and Control) *[[Food and Drug Administration (Philippines)|Food and Drug Administration]] *Health Emergency Management Bureau *Health Facility Development Bureau (formerly National Center For Health Facilities Development) *Health Human Resources Development Bureau *Health Policy Development and Planning Bureau
==Attached agencies and hospitals== ===Attached agencies=== The following agencies and councils are attached to the DOH for policy and program coordination: *Commission on Population (POPCOM) *Local Water Utilities Administration *[[National Nutrition Council (Philippines)|National Nutrition Council]] (NNC) *[[Philippine Health Insurance Corporation]] (PHIC; PhilHealth) Bida *Philippine Institute for Traditional and Alternative Health Care (PITAHC) *Philippine International Trading Corporation - Pharma (PITC - Pharma) *Philippine National AIDS Council (PNAC)
===Retained hospitals=== The following hospitals are directly under the DOH:<ref>{{cite web|title=DOH Hospitals|url=http://www.doh.gov.ph/doh-hospital.html|accessdate=18 January 2013}}</ref> {| class="wikitable" |- !DOH Hospitals !Specialty Hospitals |- | *Amang Rodriguez Medical Center *[[Dr. Jose Fabella Memorial Hospital]] *[[Corazon Locsin Montelibano Memorial Regional Hospital]] *East Avenue Medical Center *[[José R. Reyes Memorial Medical Center]] *[[National Center for Mental Health]] *National Children's Hospital *[[Philippine Orthopedic Center]] *Quirino Memorial Medical Center *[[Research Institute for Tropical Medicine]] *Rizal Medical Center *San Lazaro Hospital *[[Tondo Medical Center]] *Baguio General Hospital and Medical Center | *[[Lung Center of the Philippines]] *[[National Kidney and Transplant Institute]] *[[Philippine Children's Medical Center]] *[[Philippine Heart Center]] *Reproductive Health Clinic (9 branches) |}

{{use mdy dates|date=July 2018}} [[File:מחאת הנכים להעלאת קצבת הנכות.jpg|right|thumb|Demonstration and blocking of the road near the Knesset building with [[Member of Knesset]] [[Dov Khenin]], [[Jerusalem]], September 2017.]] [[File:Protesting handicapped person.svg|right|thumb|A protesting Disabled person, 2015.]]
[[Disability]] rights in Israel are based among the rest upon [[Disability pension|disabillity pensions]], [[Accessibility|accessibility]] [[Regulation|regulations]], [[Therapy|therapy]], [[Special education|special education]], [[Sheltered workshop|sheltered workshop]] and [[Assisted living|assisted living]].
Since the beginning of the [[21st century]], the disabled people in [[Israel]], with a population of 250,000,<ref>{{Cite web|author=Zeev Klein|url=http://www.israelhayom.co.il/article/531779|title=The Ministerial Committee on Legislation approved: The disabled pension will be raised|website=[[Israel Hayom]]|language=he|date=2017-09-18|access-date=2018-05-20}}</ref> have managed to equalize the disability pension from the [[Bituah Leumi]] (National Insurance Institute of Israel) to the [[Minimum wage|minimum wage]] level in Israel. As of 2017,<ref>{{Cite web|author=Itay Blumental and Omri Efraim|url=https://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-4975432,00.html|title=Disabled Israelis demonstrating in Tel Aviv: Our war of independence|website=[[Ynetnews]]|date=2017-06-13|access-date=2018-05-26}}</ref> the struggle was made by [[Demonstration (protest)|demonstrations]], [[Sit-in|blocking]] main roads, highways and industries, activity in [[social networking service]]s, [[petition]]s to the [[Supreme Court of Israel#High Court of Justice|High Court of Justice]], [[Negotiation|negotiations]] with the [[Cabinet of Israel|Government of Israel]] and [[Bill (law)|bills]] in the [[Knesset]].
In 2017, a full disability pension was 2,342 [[Israeli new shekel|ILS]].<ref>{{Cite web|author=Telem Yahav|url=https://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-5000945,00.html|title=Disabled protest against NIS 2,342 disability benefits|website=[[Ynetnews]]|date=2017-08-09|access-date=2018-05-26}}</ref> The minimum wage in this year was 5,000 ILS, and in December 2017 it went up to 5,300 ILS per month.<ref name=minimum>{{Cite web|author=National Insurance Institute of Israel|url=https://www.btl.gov.il/English%20Homepage/Mediniyut/GeneralInformation/Pages/MinimumWage.aspx|title=General Information – Minimum Wage|website=[[Bituah Leumi]]|date=2018-05-28|access-date=2018-05-28}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|author=Max Schindler|url=https://www.jpost.com/Israel-News/Knesset-votes-to-raise-monthly-minimum-wage-to-NIS-5300-508263|title=Knesset votes to raise monthly minimum wage to NIS 5,300|website=[[The Jerusalem Post]]|date=2017-10-24|access-date=2018-05-26}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|author=Amiram Barkat|url=http://www.globes.co.il/en/article-israels-minimum-monthly-wage-to-rise-to-nis-5300-1001208922|title=The minimum wage will be raised by NIS 300 in December, and will rise 23% in three years|website=[[Globes]]|date=2017-10-24|access-date=2018-05-26}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|author=Telem Yahav and Gad Lior|url=https://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-5035109,00.html|title=Minimum wage to rise to NIS 5,300 in December|website=[[Ynetnews]]|date=2017-10-29|access-date=2018-05-26}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|author=TOI staff|url=https://www.timesofisrael.com/minimum-wage-rising-to-nis-5300-on-december-1/|title=Minimum wage rising to NIS 5,300 on December 1|website=[[The Times of Israel]]|date=2017-10-30|access-date=2018-05-26}}</ref>
== Background == The General Disability Pension was linked to the national average salary in Israel, as it was determined in the National Insurance Law [combined version], 1995<ref>[[s:he:חוק_הביטוח_הלאומי|the National Insurance Law]] in the Hebrew Wikisource.</ref>, but in an amendment from 2003, it was determined in article 110 of the Law, that the pension will be linked to the Consumer Price Index.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.pensiondevelopment.org/123/israel.htm|title=Knowledge center – Country Database – Israel|website=Pension and Development Network|quote=Benefits are adjusted annually in January according to the increase in the consumer price index in the previous year.|date=2010|access-date=2018-05-28}}</ref><ref name=Katz>{{Cite web|author=Amir Alon|url=https://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-5048224,00.html|title=Plan adds NIS 1.98 billion in funding for disability pensions|website=[[Ynetnews]]|date=2017-11-26|access-date=2018-05-28}}</ref>
In January 2000, the minimum wage was 2,797.75 ILS,<ref name=minimum /> and the disability pension in Israel was 2,239 ILS,<ref>{{Cite web|author=Lee Yaron|url=https://www.haaretz.co.il/news/education/.premium-1.4149311|title=The disabled organizations petitioned the High Court of Justice against the state following the postponement of the increase in allowances|website=[[Haaretz]]|quote=In 2000, the monthly disability pension stood at 2,239 ILS.|date=2017-06-06|access-date=2018-05-28}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|author=Tal Carmon|url=http://www.davar1.co.il/80287/|title=Disability pensions: Burden of proof|website=Davar1 ("In the first place")|language=he|quote=To the petition were attached data according to which in 2000, the monthly disability pension stood at 2,239 ILS.|date=2017-08-09|access-date=2018-05-28}}</ref> 80 [[percent]] of the minimum wage. However, even in 2000 the disabled people demanded to equalize their pension to the minimum wage.
Most of the disabled Israelis who are entitled to a full disability pension and are permanently dependent on it for work incapacity, do not receive any other allowance. Those who receive an additional special allowance, receive it for special needs such as nursing or mobility, and it does not cover the costs to which it is intended. In addition, the designated allowances are not for basic subsistence needs.
The disability pension in Israel was one of the lowest in the [[OECD]] countries: In 2007, Israel was ranked 26th out of 31 countries. An examination conducted by OECD in 2007 also found that the disability benefit per capita in Israel was approximately 80 percent lower than the average allowance per capita in the OECD countries. In 2004, Israel raised the threshold of the sole [[Physiological functional capacity|Medical Disability]] from 40 percent to 60 percent, as the eligibility for Disability pension.<ref>{{Cite web|author=Shelly Levy, Senior Research Coordinator|url=http://www.knesset.gov.il/mmm/data/pdf/m02699.pdf|title=General Disability Pension in Israel|website=[[Knesset]]|language=he|publisher=pages 8, 4|date=2010-11-02|access-date=2018-05-30}}</ref> On June 10, 2018, the [[National Insurance Institute of Israel|National Insurance Institute]] advertised an extensive research which found that the allowances in Israel were one of the lowest in the [[Western world]], and wrote: "Israel's Social Security System is characterized by a very low level of generosity".<ref>{{Cite web|author=Amir Alon|url=https://www.ynet.co.il/articles/0,7340,L-5283551,00.html|title=National Insurance Institute study: Allowances in Israel – one of the lowest in the Western world|website=[[Ynet]]|language=he|date=2018-06-10|access-date=2018-06-11}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|author=Jacques Bendelac|url=https://www.btl.gov.il/Publications/survey/Documents/seker_296.pdf|title=The Social Protection System in Israel and in OECD Countries, 2017|website=[[National Insurance Institute of Israel|Btl]]|language=he|date=April 2018|access-date=2018-06-11}}</ref>
=== Legislative Initiatives === On December 7, 2016, the Knesset approved in a preliminary reading, by a majority of 42 to 39, a law proposal, which had been submitted by [[Member of Knesset|MK]] [[Ilan Gilon]] to equalize the basic disability pension to the minimum wage.<ref>{{Cite web|author=Moran Azulay|url=https://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-4890730,00.html|title=Pandemonium in coalition following Knesset vote loss|website=[[Ynetnews]]|date=2016-12-09|access-date=2018-06-01}}</ref> Some months earlier, MK [[Nava Boker]] also submitted on February 28, 2016, a bill to link the disability pension to the minimum wage. The difference between her bill and Gilon's bill was that by Boker's bill, payments to the disabled from private insurances would be reduced from the disability allowance.<ref>{{Cite web|author=Zvi Zerahia|url=https://www.themarker.com/news/1.2866736|title=Bill: The disability pension would be doubled to 4,650 ILS|website=[[TheMarker]]|language=he|date=2016-02-28|access-date=2018-06-26}}</ref> Boker's bill which received 82 signatures of Knesset members, was transferred to the [[Israel Democracy Institute#Legal opinions to the Ministerial Committee on Legislation|Ministerial Committee on Legislation]], but was postponed several times.<ref>{{Cite web|author=Moran Azulay|url=https://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-4996832,00.html|title=Disabled pension increase frozen while Knesset on recess|website=[[Ynetnews]]|date=2017-07-31|access-date=2018-06-01}}</ref>
=== The Zelekha Committee === Following the discussion in the Ministerial Committee on Legislation, in mid-February 2017 the [[Ministry of Finance (Israel)|Minister of Finance]] [[Moshe Kahlon]] appointed Professor [[Yaron Zelekha]], in cooperation with the "Necheh, Lo Hetzi Ben Adam" ([[Disabled, Not Half a Human Being]]) Association led by [[Alex Fridman]], to the head of a special commission to examine raising disability payments. In May 2017, Zelekha recommended an increase in the disability pension to 4,000 ILS per month in three stages, linkage of the pension to the Consumer Price Index plus one percent, raising the disregard (the amount which is allowed to earn) to the Minimum Wage level, equalizing payment of a nursing worker to the minimum wage, pension under a work disability and not only a physical disability, increasing pension of elderly disabled, and broadening the range of the mobility allowance.<ref>{{Cite web|author=Lee Yaron|url=https://www.haaretz.com/israel-news/.premium-monthly-disability-benefits-should-rise-to-over-1-000-panel-says-1.5471677|title=Monthly Disability Benefits Should Rise to Over $1,000, Israeli Panel Recommends|website=[[Haaretz]]|date=2017-05-14|access-date=2018-06-02}}</ref>
=== The Simhon Committee === In May 2017 the [[Prime Minister of Israel]] [[Benjamin Netanyahu]] appointed Professor Avi Simhon,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://departments.agri.huji.ac.il/economics/teachers/simhon_avi/|title=Avi Simhon|website=[[Hebrew University of Jerusalem]]|access-date=2018-06-15}}</ref> chairman of the National Economic Council in the Prime Minister's Office, as a chairman of another committee with representatives from the Ministry of Finance, [[Ministry of Social Affairs and Social Services]], [[Ministry of Health (Israel)|Ministry of Health]] and the National Insurance Institute.<ref>{{Cite web|author=Adrian Filot|url=https://www.calcalist.co.il/local/articles/0,7340,L-3712967,00.html|title=Netanyahu decided: A joint committee will determine the addition to the disabled pension|website=[[Calcalist]]|language=he|date=2017-05-10|access-date=2018-06-15}}</ref><ref name=simhon>{{Cite web|author=Itay Blumenthal|url=https://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-4964107,00.html|title=Disabled protest blocks major Tel Aviv intersection|website=[[Ynetnews]]|publisher=Length 1:19 minutes|date=2017-05-18|access-date=2018-06-15}}</ref> The Commission's recommendations were submitted after about a month. The allowance for a disabled person under this scheme would be 3,200 ILS and would be given to people with disabilities at the rate of 75% or more who were defined as poor, while the disregard of a salary would be decreased from 5,300 ILS (the minimum wage) to 4,200 ILS.<ref>{{Cite web|author=Hamodia Staff|url=https://hamodia.com/2017/06/13/disabled-demonstrate-increased-benefits/|title=Disabled People Demonstrate for Increased Benefits|website=[[Hamodia]]|date=2017-06-13|access-date=2018-06-15}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|author=Lee Yaron|url=https://www.haaretz.com/israel-news/.premium-israeli-panel-to-recommend-lower-disability-benefits-1.5484016|title=Israeli Panel to Recommend Lower Disability Benefits as Netanyahu Breaks Promise|website=[[Haaretz]]|date=2017-06-14|access-date=2018-06-15}}</ref>
On June 22, 2017, MK [[David Bitan]], [[Coalition government|Coalition]] chairman, convened a [[News conference]] and said that he rejected the recommendation of Simhon Committee to 3,200 ILS, and agreed with the [[Opposition (politics)|Opposition]] to accept 4,000 ILS recommended by Zelekha Committee.<ref>{{Cite web|author=Globes correspondent|url=http://en.globes.co.il/en/article-coalition-opposition-agree-nis-4000-disabled-allowance-1001193795|title=Coalition, opposition agree: NIS 4,000 disabled allowance|website=[[Globes]]|date=2017-06-22|access-date=2018-06-26}}</ref>
With the establishment of the Simhon Committee, the disabled people reacted by repeated blockings of major roads in Israel such as the entrance to [[Ben Gurion Airport|Ben Gurion International Airport]] from [[Highway 1 (Israel)|Highway 1]],<ref>{{Cite web|author=Omri Efraim|url=https://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-4978939,00.html|title=Disabled protestors block airport entrance, threaten to set themselves on fire|website=[[Ynetnews]]|date=2017-06-21|access-date=2018-06-03}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|author=Constructive Criticism 2013|url=https://www.facebook.com/bikoretbona2013/posts/1972107729667836|title=Disabled people blocked the entrance to Ben Gurion Airport for two hours|website=[[Facebook]]|language=he|publisher=Length 7:47 minutes|date=2017-06-21|access-date=2018-06-24}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|author=Lee Yaron and Yaniv Kubovich|url=https://www.haaretz.com/israel-news/.premium-disabled-israelis-protest-block-road-to-airport-over-benefits-1.5487202|title=Disabled Israelis Protest Meager Increase in Benefits, Block Road to Airport|website=[[Haaretz]]|date=2017-06-21|access-date=2018-06-03}}</ref> the [[Highway 20 (Israel)|Ayalon Highway]], [[Highway 4 (Israel)|Highway 4]], [[Ra'anana]] Junction, the [[Highway 2 (Israel)|Coastal Road]] and the entrance to Jerusalem, near the [[Chords Bridge]].<ref name=simhon /><ref name=ofer>{{Cite web|author=Liran Levy|url=https://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-4959182,00.html|title=Road to Jerusalem opened after disabled demonstrators block access in protest of low government assistance|website=[[Ynetnews]]|date=2017-05-08|access-date=2018-06-03}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|author=Aharon Rabinovich, Yotam Berger and Lee Yaron|url=https://www.haaretz.co.il/news/education/.premium-1.4210789|title=After approval of the limited benefits outline: The disabled blocked the entrance to Jerusalem|website=[[Haaretz]]|language=he|date=2017-06-27|access-date=2018-06-03}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|author=Amir Alon and Raanan Ben Zur|url=https://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-5006389,00.html|title=Disabled protests: demonstrators block coastal highway near Hadera|website=[[Ynetnews]]|date=2017-08-22|access-date=2018-06-03}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|author=Amir Alon and Raanan Ben Zur|url=https://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-5007092,00.html|title=Highway 4 blocked from Geha Interchange towards Givat Shmuel due to disabled people's protest|website=[[Ynetnews]]|date=2017-08-24|access-date=2018-06-03}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|author=Omri Efraim|url=https://www.ynet.co.il/articles/0,7340,L-4986547,00.html|title=The Struggle of the Disabled: Protesters blocked Highway 4 in the Sharon area and burned tires|website=[[Ynet]]|language=he|publisher=Length 2:26 minutes|date=2017-09-07|access-date=2018-06-03}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|author=Amir Alon|url=https://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-5020083,00.html|title=Disabled protestors block Coastal Highway|website=[[Ynetnews]]|date=2017-09-24|access-date=2018-06-06}}</ref>
The demonstrators claimed that for decades they had demonstrated in front of the Knesset, the Ministry of Finance and the roads, but the government and the public ignored their demands. Therefore they had to turn to roadblocks. Initially, the [[Israel Police]] did not take proactive enforcement action against roadblocks, but with increasing traffic disturbances, The police began to take a more severe hand, and some of the obstructions included clashes between the police and the handicapped, and several disabled people were arrested.<ref>{{Cite web|author=Amir Alon|url=https://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-5002255,00.html|title=Four disabled protesters arrested after assaulting policemen|website=[[Ynetnews]]|publisher=Length 0:49 minutes, length 0:28 minutes|date=2017-08-13|access-date=2018-06-03}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|author=Constructive Criticism 2013|url=https://www.facebook.com/bikoretbona2013/posts/2106242439587697|title=The violent arrest of disabled people in the Ashdod area. The police blocked the convoy of the disabled people to Ashdod at a checkpoint with a police ambush near the Ashdod interchange, and arrested 5 disabled people. Photographed on 2017-08-13|website=[[Facebook]]|language=he|publisher=Length 15:51 minutes|date=2018-04-23|access-date=2018-07-22}}</ref> In September 2017, the police issued a statement saying that it would no longer allow roadblocks in demonstrations, and that it would begin to fine the demonstrators who blocked roads.<ref>{{Cite web|author=Yaniv Kubovich|url=https://www.haaretz.co.il/news/politics/.premium-1.4461246|title=The Police to the Disabled organizers of the Demonstrations: We will not allow more roadblocks|website=[[Haaretz]]|language=he|date=2017-09-24|access-date=2018-06-05}}</ref> The police added that it "will continue to allow freedom of expression and protest by law, but will not allow a public order to be violated and such a significant violation of the normal fabric of life of Israeli citizens".<ref>{{Cite web|author=Amir Alon|url=https://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-5021678,00.html|title=Disabled demonstrators clash with police in Herzliya protest|website=[[Ynetnews]]|publisher=Length 1:46 minutes|date=2017-09-27|access-date=2018-06-05}}</ref>
A week before the submission of the conclusions of the Simhon Committee, disabled representatives appealed to the High Court following the postponement of allowances increasing. In its response to the petition, the state claimed that the petitioners did not prove that the disability allowance of 2,342 ILS a month would not allow the right to live with dignity.<ref>{{Cite web|author=Lee Yaron|url=https://www.haaretz.co.il/news/politics/.premium-1.4149311|title=The Disabled Organizations petitioned the High Court of Justice against the state, following the postponement of raising the allowances|website=[[Haaretz]]|language=he|date=2017-06-06|access-date=2018-06-05}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|author=Lee Yaron and Yaniv Kubovich|url=https://www.haaretz.com/israel-news/.premium-disabled-activists-keep-up-protests-with-new-roadblocks-1.5453193|title=Disabled Activists in Israel Block Major Highways in Protest of Stagnant Disability Allowances|website=[[Haaretz]]|date=2017-09-25|access-date=2018-06-05}}</ref> On June 18, 2018, the chief justice [[Esther Hayut]] cancelled the petition in the High Court. She adjudicated that the disability pension has already been raised by [[legislation]] in February 2018,<ref name=legislation>{{Cite web|author=TOI staff|url=https://www.timesofisrael.com/knesset-raises-disability-benefits-as-protesters-push-for-bigger-boost/|title=Knesset raises disability benefits as protesters push for bigger boost|website=[[The Times of Israel]]|date=2018-02-13|access-date=2018-06-19}}</ref> and the petition should be corrected due to this raise.<ref>{{Cite web|author=Lee Yaron|url=https://www.haaretz.co.il/news/education/.premium-1.6180928|title=The High Court of Justice ordered the cancellation of the petition of disability organizations to equalize the disability pension to the minimum wage|website=[[Haaretz]]|language=he|date=2018-06-18|access-date=2018-06-19}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|author=High Court|url=https://supremedecisions.court.gov.il/Home/Download?path=HebrewVerdicts%5C17%5C630%5C045%5Cv10&fileName=17045630.V10&type=2|title=High Court verdict at file 4563/17|website=[[Supreme Court of Israel]]|language=he|date=2018-06-18|access-date=2018-06-19}}</ref>
On September 4, 2017, the Disabled people demonstrated outside the [[Histadrut]] offices in [[Tel Aviv]].<ref>{{Cite web|author=Itay Blumenthal|url=https://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-5011817,00.html|title=Disabled protesters demonstrate outside Histadrut Labor Federation's offices in Tel Aviv|website=[[Ynetnews]]|date=2017-09-04|access-date=2018-06-05}}</ref> On September 5, 2017, the Histadrut Chairman Avi Nissenkorn<ref>{{Twitter|AviNissenkorn|Avi Nissenkorn}}</ref> met with the Disabled people's organizations, and told them that the Histadrut would be a full partner in their struggle.<ref>{{Cite web|author=Itay Blumenthal|url=https://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-5012498,00.html|title=Nissenkorn meets with disabled protestors, assures them Histadrut a full partner|website=[[Ynetnews]]|date=2017-09-05|access-date=2018-06-05}}</ref>
On September 18, 2017, there was a special plenum session in the Knesset, due to the delay in legislation, which resulted a submission of tens of MKs signatures to [[Yuli-Yoel Edelstein|Yuli Edelstein]], the [[List of Knesset speakers|Speaker of the Knesset]]. The subject of the session was the government's maltreatment in the disabled people.<ref name=Knesset>{{Cite web|author=The Knesset|url=http://fs.knesset.gov.il//20/Plenum/20_ptm_390969.doc|title=Special conference: The 261st session of the 20th Knesset. Agenda proposal: The government's maltreatment in the disabled people|website=[[Knesset]]|language=he|date=2017-09-18|access-date=2018-06-26}}</ref> Some MKs, as the former Minister of Finance [[Yair Lapid]], attacked the government.<ref>{{Cite web|author=Yair Lapid|url=https://www.facebook.com/YairLapid/posts/1609682055756806|title=The struggle of the disabled is justified, there is no one who can argue with this demand. On the moral level. On the practical level. It is impossible to live from 2,342 ILS a month.|website=[[Facebook]]|language=he|date=2017-09-18|access-date=2018-06-26}}</ref> The session ended with a vote of 49 votes, with no opposition, to pass the issue to one of the Knesset committees.<ref name=Knesset />
=== Negotiation in the Histadrut === Toward the end of September 2017, Naomi Moravia, chairwoman of the "Israeli Human Rights Organization of People with Disabilities", which was located in the Histadrut building in Tel Aviv, asked for Nissenkorn assistance in opposition to the government.<ref>{{Cite web|author=Tal Carmon and Nitzan Zvi Cohen|url=http://www.davar1.co.il/87407|title=The struggle for the Disability Pensions: Working with the Disabled|website=Davar1|language=he|date=2017-09-27|access-date=2018-06-05}}</ref> Following her request, Nissenkorn convened on the night of September 29, 2017, a night meeting at the Histadrut of representatives of disabled people with him, with MK Ilan Gilon and MK David Bitan, and with Avi Simhon. After 12 hours of negotiations until the morning hours, during which Yehuda Doron, a representative of the [[Poliomyelitis|Polio]] Handicapped Association, retired from the discussion, and Dr. Amichai Tamir of the Disabled Organization remained in the discussion, but opposed the outline, it was agreed to supplement the disability pension in four stages until 2021, so that the final allowance would be 3,800 up to 4,000 ILS for the disabled and 4,050 ILS for 30 thousand individuals with above 80% disability. The sum of the disregard would be raised in two stages to 4,000 ILS in January 2018 and to 4,300 ILS in January 2019. The budgetary cost of the outline was 4.2 billion ILS, and it was agreed that the addition of 340 to 540 ILS for Disabled people, would start in January 2018.<ref>{{Cite web|author=Amir Alon|url=https://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-5022695,00.html|title=Agreement reached, disability pensions will be raised|website=[[Ynetnews]]|date=2017-09-29|access-date=2018-06-15}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|author=TOI staff|url=https://www.timesofisrael.com/after-protests-state-agrees-to-up-disability-benefits-to-over-nis-4000/|title=After protests, state agrees to up disability benefits to over NIS 4,000|website=[[The Times of Israel]]|date=2017-09-29|access-date=2018-06-15}}</ref> On October 1, 2017, Simhon claimed that the government could only commit to an addition of 1.3 billion ILS for 2018, and would not commit itself to the coming years.<ref>{{Cite web|author=Adrian Filot|url=https://www.calcalist.co.il/local/articles/0,7340,L-3722184,00.html|title=Avi Simhon on the agreement with the disabled: There is no possibility of committing to the rest of the additions for the years to come|website=[[Calcalist]]|language=he|date=2017-10-01|access-date=2018-06-05}}</ref> Simhon explained that a computer program (a software agent) which was called Numerator,<ref>{{Cite web|author=Lahav Harkov|url=https://www.jpost.com/International/What-has-the-government-done-for-us-lately-502749|title=What has Israel's Government done for its Citizens lately?|website=[[The Jerusalem Post]]|quote=So, why aren’t a third of government decisions implemented? In short, because of bureaucracy and politics. The expected answer, budgets, is in reality less of a problem, because funding for three years is built into all government planning, as part of a recent Finance Ministry initiative called the numerator.|date=2017-08-19|access-date=2018-06-05}}</ref> limited the government's commitment without an appropriate budget clause, and therefore the inability to commit to 4.2 billion ILS.
== The Responses of the Disabled == Simhon's remarks about the inability to commit to 4.2 billion ILS, along with the expected addition in January 2018 of 340 ILS to the disabled and the four stages up to 2021, caused most disabled people to deny the outline which had been reached between the organizations "Israeli Human Rights Organization of People with Disabilities" and "Necheh Lo Hetzi Ben Adam" and the Government, with the assistance of Nissenkorn.
The organizations "The Disabled Panthers" led by Eyal Cohen, "The [[A-team]] Disabled" under the leadership of Ofer Sofer, the organization of the disabled, led by Tamir, and the Polio organization led by Doron, announced that they would continue to block roads until the disability pension would be equal to the minimum wage and would be paid with one stage.<ref>{{Cite web|author=Sarah Levi|url=http://www.jpost.com/Israel-News/The-fight-Minimum-wages-on-The-battle-may-be-won-but-the-war-continues-506422|title=The fight for Minimum Wage: The battle may be won but the war continues|website=[[The Jerusalem Post]]|date=2017-10-01|access-date=2018-06-15}}</ref><ref name=helman>{{Cite web|author=Amir Alon|url=https://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-5023107,00.html|title=Disabled Panthers block road over benefits agreement|website=[[Ynetnews]]|date=2017-10-01|access-date=2018-06-15}}</ref>
Oren Helman, a Vice President of the [[Israel Electric Corporation]], a father of a daughter with a disability, and a former advisor to Netanyahu for a year when Netanyahu was the [[Finance Minister]], also published an article in the newspaper [[Globes]] after advertising the Histadrut outline, and demanded to increase the amount of the disregard to 15,000 ILS.<ref name=helman /><ref>{{Cite web|author=Oren Helman|url=https://www.globes.co.il/news/article.aspx?did=1001206683|title=We missed the Integration of People with a Disability at Work|website=[[Globes]]|language=he|date=2017-09-29|access-date=2018-06-15}}</ref>
=== Intensification of the protest === [[File:Hanna_Akiva1.jpg|right|thumb|Hanna Akiva is blocking the entrance to [[Port of Ashdod]], October 3, 2017.]] [[File:Blocking Israeli Prime Minister Residence1.jpg|right|thumb|The demonstration of the disabled in front of the prime minister's residence on October 17, 2017, with Eyal Cohen, Hanna Akiva (in red), Iris Haya Zigdon (in blue)<ref>{{Cite web|author=Eitan Glickman|url=https://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-5013049,00.html|title=Policewoman feeds disabled protester in touching display of humanity|website=[[Ynetnews]]|date=2017-09-06|access-date=2018-08-27}}</ref> and Raanan Kerklies, who passed away on May 23, 2018,<ref>{{Cite web|author=Melanie Roiter|url=https://www.facebook.com/melroiter/posts/1909655919096088|title=Raanan Kerklies 1954–2018|website=[[Facebook]]|date=2018-05-23|access-date=2018-06-06}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|author=[[Keren Neubach]]|url=https://www.facebook.com/keren.neubach/posts/10156339658564513|title=At this hour Raanan Kerklies is being brought to his rest at the Kiryat Tivon cemetery|website=[[Facebook]]|language=he|date=2018-05-24|access-date=2018-06-06}}</ref> in a gray shirt with his back to the camera. Balfour Street, Jerusalem.]] [[File:Blocking Israeli Prime Minister Residence2.jpg|right|thumb|Police [[Yasam]] team in front of the disabled people at the prime minister's residence. Facing the camera – Eyal Cohen, the leader of "The Disabled Panthers", Kerklies was left to him, and behind him – Yehuda Doron (in white) and Zigdon. Shachaf Mahfood, a "Disabled Panthers" activist, held a handheld extendable pole, recording the demonstration by her smartphone's camera. Balfour Street, Jerusalem, October 17, 2017.]] On October 3, 2017, the members of "The Disabled Panthers" and "The A-team" blocked two entrances to the [[Port of Ashdod]] from six in the morning for five hours, causing heavy financial damage. The demonstrators agreed to evacuate the entrances to the port after the police agreed to void the traffic tickets which it recorded on their vehicles.<ref>{{Cite web|author=Amir Alon|url=https://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-5024160,00.html|title=Disabled protest: protesters blocking entry to Ashdod port|website=[[Ynetnews]]|date=2017-10-03|publisher=07:40 am|access-date=2018-06-06}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|author=Amir Alon|url=https://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-5024267,00.html|title=Disabled protest: protesters blocking entry to Ashdod port receive traffic tickets|website=[[Ynetnews]]|date=2017-10-03|publisher=10:53 am|access-date=2018-06-06}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|author=Amir Alon|url=https://www.ynet.co.il/articles/0,7340,L-5024211,00.html|title=After 5 hours: The Disabled people were evacuated and the Ashdod port was opened|website=[[Ynet]]|language=he|date=2017-10-03|publisher=11:16 am Length 2:24 minutes|access-date=2018-06-06}}</ref> On October 9, 2017, during the [[Sukkot]] holiday, representatives of the disabled were hosted by the [[President of Israel|President]] [[Reuven Rivlin]] at the president's succah (tabernacle), which was opened to the general public. The president asked the disabled to hold a dignified dialogue with all the professional bodies.<ref name=president>{{Cite web|author=Davar1|url=http://www.davar1.co.il/89030/23|title=Equalizing Disability pensions: The Disabled went to Jerusalem|website=Davar1|language=he|date=2017-10-09|access-date=2018-06-06}}</ref> Then the disabled went and demonstrated outside the house of the [[Ministry of Interior (Israel)|Interior Minister]] [[Aryeh Deri]] in the rain. From Deri, they went to the Prime Minister's residence on Balfour street, and blocked [[Gaza Street]].<ref name=president /> From there they moved to {{ill|France Square|simple|Paris Square (Jerusalem)}}, and blocked the traffic. On October 15, for the first time in cooperation with representatives of disabled [[Israel Defense Forces|IDF]] veterans, the disabled disrupted the southern traffic on the Coastal Road near Netanya by driving slowly on the road, with the approval and in coordination with the police.<ref>{{Cite web|author=Amir Alon|url=https://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-5028401,00.html|title=Disabled Panthers block coastal road to the south|website=[[Ynetnews]]|date=2017-10-15|access-date=2018-06-06}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|author=Dana Yarkzi|url=https://news.walla.co.il/item/3103487|title=At the height of the rush: Activists of the Disabled Protest disrupted the movement in the Netanya area|website=[[Walla!]]|language=he|quote=For about an hour, the demonstrators disrupted traffic on the highway, which was reduced by the police to two separate routes. Later, the police blocked the road in order to allow the demonstrators to return to the starting point at the gas station near the Netanya interchange.|publisher=Length 0:47 minutes|date=2017-10-15|access-date=2018-06-06}}</ref>
On October 17, 2017, disabled people gathered at a gas station near the [[Latrun Interchange]], and from there they drove slowly on Highway 1 to Jerusalem, causing heavy traffic. They arrived at the Prime Minister's house and blocked the southern entrance gate on Balfour Street. [[Nicole Raidman]] arrived and caused a media storm when she gave 2,000 ILS to [[Hanna Akiva]] from "The Disabled Panthers".<ref>{{Cite web|author=TOI staff|url=https://www.timesofisrael.com/socialite-stuns-disabled-rights-protester-by-handing-her-a-wad-of-cash|title=Socialite stuns disabled-rights protester by handing her a wad of cash|website=[[The Times of Israel]]|publisher=Length 1:20 minutes|date=2017-10-18|access-date=2018-06-06}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|author=Allison Kaplan Sommer|url=https://www.haaretz.com/israel-news/.premium-the-celebrity-socialite-who-lives-large-with-the-netanyahus-1.5459042|title=The Controversial Celebrity Socialite Who Lives Large With the Netanyahus|website=[[Haaretz]]|publisher=Length 1:20 minutes|date=2017-10-19|access-date=2018-06-06}}</ref> Then the Panthers' spokesman clarified that the money was transferred to cover their expenses, and was not used personally. After blocking the Prime Minister's residence, they blocked Keren Hayesod Street in Jerusalem, blocked Paris Square,<ref>{{Cite web|author=Amir Alon|url=https://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-5029878,00.html|title=Disabled protest: Jerusalem's Paris Square blocked by protestors|website=[[Ynetnews]]|date=2017-10-17|publisher=4:33 pm|access-date=2018-06-06}}</ref> and from there they went to the Chords Bridge and blocked the entrance to Jerusalem until evening,<ref>{{Cite web|author=Amir Alon|url=https://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-5029929,00.html|title=Disabled protest: Exit and entrance to Jerusalem blocked near Chords Bridge|website=[[Ynetnews]]|date=2017-10-17|publisher=6:23 pm|access-date=2018-06-06}}</ref> under the supervision of the police.
With the return of the Knesset to the Winter Session on October 23, 2017, disabled people from 15 organizations<ref>{{Cite web|author=Yisrael Price|url=https://hamodia.com/2017/10/22/ben-gurion-airport-next-target-disabled-protest-campaign/|title=Ben Gurion Airport Next Target of Disabled Protest Campaign|website=[[Hamodia]]|date=2017-10-22|access-date=2018-06-08}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|author=Amir Alon|url=https://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-5032254,00.html|title=Disabled objecting to deal with government threaten to shut down Ben Gurion Airport|website=[[Ynetnews]]|date=2017-10-23|access-date=2018-06-07}}</ref> set up a tent opposite the Knesset, and clashed with its security guards in an attempt to break into the territory of the Knesset. The police closed [[Kiryat HaMemshala|Kaplan Street]] to traffic. When Naomi Moravia left the Knesset, the disabled people burst out, shouting at her, and security guards accompanied her out.<ref>{{Cite web|author=Sarah Levi|url=https://www.jpost.com/Israel-News/Pitching-a-tent-for-justice-disabled-Israelis-continue-protests-for-livable-wage-508218|title=Pitching a tent for Justice: Disabled Israelis continue protests for livable wage|website=[[The Jerusalem Post]]|date=2017-10-23|access-date=2018-06-15}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|author=Amir Alon|url=https://www.ynet.co.il/articles/0,7340,L-5032438,00.html|title=The Disabled set up a protest tent in front of the Knesset: Planning a day of rage|website=[[Ynet]]|language=he|date=2017-10-23|access-date=2018-06-15}}</ref> The disabled also blocked the entrances to the Ministry of Finance.<ref>{{Cite web|author=Hagai Amit|url=https://www.themarker.com/news/macro/1.4546904|title=Protest of the Disabled: Protesters Block Access to the Ministry of Finance|website=[[TheMarker]]|language=he|date=2017-10-25|access-date=2018-06-07}}</ref>
On November 5, 2017, members of "the Disabled Panthers" blocked the entrances and exits at the [[Oil Refineries|Haifa Oil Refineries]] for four and a half hours.<ref>{{Cite web|author=Amir Alon|url=https://www.ynet.co.il/articles/0,7340,L-5038494,00.html|title=The Disabled people blocked the entrance to the Refineries for 4.5 hours|website=[[Ynet]]|language=he|publisher=Length 2:55 minutes|date=2017-11-05|access-date=2018-06-07}}</ref> The security personnel of the Refineries went out to the protestors with refreshments.<ref>{{Cite web|author=The men of silence|url=http://hamal.walla.co.il/post/-Ky9iylp8Z8Vk6QiT5GS|title=The security personnel of the ORL (Oil Refineries Ltd) went out to the protesters of the Disabled Panthers with refreshments|website=[[Walla!]] Hamal|language=he|publisher=Length 0:14 minutes|date=2017-11-05|access-date=2018-06-07}}</ref>
On November 19, 2017, the Disabled people blocked the entrances and exits of the Prime Minister's Office in Jerusalem, when the weekly cabinet meeting was held there, and then blocked the [[Light rail]] traffic in Jerusalem.<ref>{{Cite web|author=Amir Alon and Yishai Porat|url=https://www.ynet.co.il/articles/0,7340,L-5044984,00.html|title=The roadblocks are back: Disabled people demonstrated at the entrance to Jerusalem and stopped the light rail traffic|website=[[Ynet]]|language=he|publisher=Length 1:23 minutes|date=2017-11-19|access-date=2018-06-07}}</ref>
On November 22, 2017, at seven o'clock in the morning, "the Disabled Panthers" blocked the exits from Bitan's home in [[Rishon LeZion]], in a similar manner to the four beats designed for the disabled. Some residents of the street tried to confront them, and the police forces in the area prevented it.<ref>{{Cite web|author=TOI STAFF|url=https://www.timesofisrael.com/disabled-activists-block-lawmakers-street/|title=Disabled activists block lawmaker’s street|website=[[The Times of Israel]]|date=2017-11-22|access-date=2018-06-08}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|author=Constructive Criticism 2013|url=https://www.facebook.com/bikoretbona2013/posts/2035178846694057|title=The Disabled Panthers in the first-time blocking in front of the David Bitan House in Rishon LeZion|website=[[Facebook]]|language=he|publisher=Length 6:11 minutes|date=2017-11-22|access-date=2018-06-08}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|author=Constructive Criticism 2013|url=https://www.facebook.com/bikoretbona2013/posts/2035628633315745|title=The Disabled Panthers in a second-stage blocking in front of the David Bitan House|website=[[Facebook]]|language=he|publisher=Length 6:27 minutes|date=2017-11-22|access-date=2018-06-08}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|author=Constructive Criticism 2013|url=https://www.facebook.com/bikoretbona2013/posts/2035674653311143|title=The Disabled Panthers in a third blocking in front of the David Bitan House|website=[[Facebook]]|language=he|publisher=Length 5:27 minutes|date=2017-11-22|access-date=2018-06-08}}</ref> From there, they went to Ben Gurion Airport and blocked the railway.<ref>{{Cite web|author=Constructive Criticism 2013|url=https://www.facebook.com/bikoretbona2013/posts/2035236136688328|title=Disabled on the railway line east of Ben Gurion Airport|website=[[Facebook]]|language=he|publisher=Length 2:33 minutes|date=2017-11-22|access-date=2018-06-08}}</ref> On November 29, 2017, they returned to Bitan's place at 5:40 in the morning, when it was still dark, and met Bitan on his way to his car, because Bitan's driver could not reach him, due to the blocking by the Panthers. Police accompanied Bitan, and the Panthers told Bitan that they would continue to block him and his neighbors until he realized that just a minimum wage would be the pension for all disabled people. Amnon Ben-Ataf followed Bitan, condemned him, told him that he disliked disabled people, and asked how his wife and his daughter could live on 2,400 ILS if they became disabled. Bitan replied to him: "Do not shout in my ear".<ref>{{Cite web|author=TOI staff|url=https://www.timesofisrael.com/disabled-activists-block-coalition-whip-david-bitans-street/|title=Disabled activists block coalition whip David Bitan’s street|website=[[The Times of Israel]]|date=2017-11-29|access-date=2018-06-09}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|author=Five with Rafi Reshef|url=http://10tv.nana10.co.il/Article/?ArticleID=1276099|title=The disabled man who cursed coalition chairman Bitan: I spoke from the blood of my heart|website=[[Nana 10]]|language=he|publisher=Length 6:10 minutes|date=2017-11-29|access-date=2018-06-09}}</ref> In response, Moravia sent a bouquet of roses to Bitan, wrote: "We are not them", and signed on behalf of her organization's members.<ref>{{Cite web|author=David Bitan|url=https://www.facebook.com/544236812346549/posts/1101858859917672|title=Shabbat Shalom to the whole Nation of Israel (Receiving a bouquet of roses from Moravia)|website=[[Facebook]]|language=he|date=2017-12-01|access-date=2018-06-09}}</ref>
== Legislation initiated by the government == On November 25, 2017, the [[Ministry of Social Affairs and Social Services|Welfare Minister of Israel]] [[Haim Katz]] announced a bill on his behalf that would be placed on the Government's table. The "Israeli Human Rights Organization of People with Disabilities" responded to Katz's bill, and rejected the non-linkage to the Average Wage in Israel, the lowering of the total amount from 4.2 billion ILS to less than 2 billion ILS, the absence of further increase of the Disregard in 2019, and the absence of further increase of the disability pension.<ref name=Katz /> On November 26, 2017, a memorandum of law was published,[64] which was the formal beginning of a legislative initiative initiated by the government for several changes in the disability pension following the agreement between the disability organizations and the government. On the same day, the disabled people demonstrated against Katz's bill, and blocked the light rail in Jerusalem for an hour.<ref>{{Cite web|author=Amir Alon|url=https://www.ynet.co.il/articles/0,7340,L-5048252,00.html|title=The Disabled oppose the new bill: We shall protest in a way which has not yet been looked alike|website=[[Ynet]]|language=he|publisher=Length 0:31 minutes|date=2017-11-27|access-date=2018-06-12}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|author=Constructive Criticism 2013|url=https://www.facebook.com/bikoretbona2013/videos/2036978066514135|title=Blocking the Light Rail for about an hour: Tough traffic disruptions on Sunday 2018-11-26. the Disabled people demand Disability Pension at the Minimum Wage level now|website=[[Facebook]]|language=he|publisher=Length 4:55 minutes|quote=Ofer Sofer: We demand the Minimum Wage and shall not give up. We will continue and will do it the whole week and the whole month, every day, every day. We shall not stop, shall not stop.|date=2017-11-26|access-date=2018-06-12}}</ref>
On December 5, 2017, at a meeting of the [[Knesset#Committees|Labor, Welfare and Health Committee]] in the Knesset, which was headed by MK [[Eli Alaluf]] on the bill submitted by MK Gilon,<ref>The MKs [[Karin Elharar]], [[Dov Khenin]], [[Yael German]], [[Michal Rozin]], [[Issawi Frej]], [[Omer Bar-Lev]] and [[Tamar Zandberg]] have joined Gilon's bill, and two additional suitable bills were discussed</ref><ref>{{Cite web|author=The Knesset|url=http://fs.knesset.gov.il//20/Committees/20_ptv_397355.doc|title=Protocol No. 649 From the meeting of the Labor, Welfare and Health Committee|website=[[Knesset]]|language=he|date=2017-12-05|access-date=2018-06-14}}</ref> a fight broke out between Arik Harari, who opposed the Histadrut's outline, and Ofer Buchnik<ref name=ofer /> of the "Israeli Human Rights Organization of People with Disabilities".<ref>{{Cite web|author=The Knesset|url=http://fs.knesset.gov.il//20/Committees/20_ptv_397355.doc|title=Protocol No. 649 From the meeting of the Labor, Welfare and Health Committee|website=[[Knesset]]|language=he|publisher=Pages 42–48. In bold letters: "One of the Disabled strikes another Disabled. Shouts and noise in the committee room. The guards stop the brawl"|date=2017-12-05|access-date=2018-06-14}}</ref> According to Harari, he responded to the touch of Gabi Hadai from the "Israeli Human Rights Organization" at Simcha Benita, the chairwoman of "Mazor" organization.<ref>{{Cite web|author=Yishai Porat and Amir Alon|url=https://www.ynet.co.il/articles/0,7340,L-5052293,00.html|title=The beatings in the Knesset: They tied my hands, I became a ninja|website=[[Ynet]]|language=he|publisher=Length 1:37 minutes|date=2017-12-05|access-date=2018-06-14}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|author=TOI staff|url=https://www.timesofisrael.com/disabled-activist-stabs-rival-with-a-pen-in-knesset-brawl/|title=Disabled activist stabs rival with a pen in Knesset brawl|website=[[The Times of Israel]]|publisher=Length 0:23 minutes|date=2017-12-05|access-date=2018-06-14}}</ref> On December 11,2017 Another meeting was held in the Labor, Welfare and Health Committee. At this meeting, MK [[Moti Yogev]] of [[The Jewish Home|the Jewish Home]] said that it was absolutely necessary that the Disability Pension would not be affected due to going out of Disabled people to work, alongside the obligation to shorten the stages. MK [[Abd al-Hakim Hajj Yahya]] of the [[Joint List]] said that disability pensions are a commitment of the state towards its citizens, and the budget of 4.2 billion ILS is not something sacred. He said that the MKs had to check with the [[Treasury]] if there was over [[Government revenue|revenue]]. By Hajj Yahya, if there was money, the stages' number should be reduced. Eyal Cohen from "the Disabled Panthers" said that he had paid to the National Insurance every month without any stages, and his doctor told him a year ago, that he would have four years to live.<ref>{{Cite web|author=The Knesset|url=http://fs.knesset.gov.il//20/Committees/20_ptv_395621.doc|title=Protocol No. 650 From the meeting of the Labor, Welfare and Health Committee|website=[[Knesset]]|language=he|date=2017-12-11|access-date=2018-06-14}}</ref>
On December 20, 2017, the Knesset approved unanimously in a preliminary vote the bill submitted by MK [[Mickey Rosenthal]] supported by Welfare Minister Katz, which would increase the allowance to 4,300 ILS in a gradual process. Katz said that a minimum wage for the disabled people probably would not happen.<ref>{{Cite web|author=Zeev Klein|url=http://www.israelhayom.co.il/article/522885|title=Gained preliminary approval: Disability Pension would rise to 4,300 ILS|website=[[Israel Hayom]]|language=he|date=2017-12-20|access-date=2018-06-13}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|author=Tal Carmon|url=http://www.davar1.co.il/100608/|title=Promises have to be fulfilled: The increase in the Disability Pensions was preliminarily approved|website=Davar1|language=he|date=2017-12-20|access-date=2018-06-13}}</ref> On December 21, 2017, "the Disabled Panthers" arrived at the home of Shai Babad, the [[Director general]] of the Finance Ministry, after Katz had said and had denied afterwards, that Babad had asserted that he totally had not cared about the Disabled.<ref>{{Cite web|author=Dana Yarkzi|url=https://news.walla.co.il/item/3121352|title=Disabled protest: Demonstrators protested near the house of the Ministry of Finance Director|website=[[Walla!]]|language=he|date=2017-12-21|access-date=2018-06-15}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|author=Constructive Criticism 2013|url=https://www.facebook.com/bikoretbona2013/videos/2048640172014591|title=Protest of the Disabled: Demonstrators outside the home of Shai Babad, Director General of the Finance Ministry, in Hod themselves in front of the house and pasted stickers of "the Disabled Panthers" on the door of his home, on the front door of his parking lot and on the street illumination.<ref>{{Cite web|author=Amir Alon|url=https://www.ynet.co.il/articles/0,7340,L-5060468,00.html|title=Protest of the Disabled: about 20 protesters are barricaded at the entrance to Netanyahu's residence in Caesarea|website=[[Ynet]]|language=he|date=2017-12-22|access-date=2018-06-15}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|author=Constructive Criticism 2013|url=https://www.facebook.com/bikoretbona2013/posts/2048833565328585|title=In front of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's residence in Caesarea|website=[[Facebook]]|language=he|publisher=Length 6:10 minutes|date=2017-12-22|access-date=2018-06-15}}</ref>
On December 29, 2017, Boker announced that on Sunday, December 31, 2017, she would submit her bill to the Ministerial Committee on Legislation for the sixth time. According to Boker, the Ministerial Committee approved the bill and attached it to the government bill.<ref>{{Cite web|author=Nava Boker|url=https://www.facebook.com/navaboker/posts/1999329507021684|title=On Sunday I will raise at the Ministerial Committee on Legislation for the sixth time my bill raising the Disabled allowances to the Minimum Wage|website=[[Facebook]]|language=he|date=2017-12-29|access-date=2018-06-15}}</ref> On January 1, 2018, Gilon convened Knesset members from the Coalition and from the Opposition to discuss the absence of legislation by the government, even though the legislative deadline passed.<ref>{{Cite web|author=Tal Carmon|url=http://www.davar1.co.il/102555/|title=The Disability Allowances: Will the legislators do a strike?|website=Davar1|language=he|date=2018-01-01|access-date=2018-06-15}}</ref>
On January 3, 2018, Netanyahu and Katz announced at a News conference that the disabled would receive an additional 161 ILS in July 2018, in addition to the planned 340 ILS.<ref name=Netanyahu>{{Cite web|author=Yael Friedson and Amir Alon|url=https://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-5065870,00.html|title=Netanyahu presents plan to increase disability benefits|website=[[Ynetnews]]|date=2018-01-03|access-date=2018-06-15}}</ref> The Disabled responded by blocking Highway 4 and burning tires,<ref name=Netanyahu /> blocking the Golf Junction in Caesarea<ref>{{Cite web|author=Amir Alon|url=https://www.ynet.co.il/articles/0,7340,L-5065822,00.html|title=Documented Confrontation: Urban Inspectors on a Disabled Protester in Caesarea|website=[[Ynet]]|language=he|publisher=Length 1:40 minutes, length 0:42 minutes (Netanyahu)|date=2018-01-03|access-date=2018-06-15}}</ref> and blocking the Power station in Hadera.<ref>{{Cite web|author=Amir Alon|url=https://www.ynet.co.il/articles/0,7340,L-5065955,00.html|title=The protest of the Disabled: The entrances and exits from the Hadera Power Plant were blocked for about an hour|website=[[Ynet]]|language=he|date=2018-01-03|access-date=2018-06-15}}</ref> On the same day, Boker's bill passed in a preliminary reading in the Knesset by 86 votes without dissent.<ref>{{Cite web|author=Nava Boker|url=https://www.facebook.com/navaboker/posts/2001865726768062|title=My bill to raise the allowances for Disabled people was passed today in a preliminary reading by a majority of 86 MKs and without opponents|website=[[Facebook]]|language=he|publisher=Length 2:00 minutes|date=2018-01-03|access-date=2018-06-15}}</ref> In an interview with [[Israel Hayom]], Katz admitted that the additions to the disabled pension were insufficient,<ref>{{Cite web|author=Zeev Klein|url=http://www.israelhayom.co.il/article/526479|title=Minister Katz admits that the additions to the disabled are insufficient|website=[[Israel Hayom]]|language=he|date=2018-01-07|access-date=2018-06-15}}</ref> and a week later, blamed the Treasury for playing game, and said that Netanyahu did not care about disabled.<ref>{{Cite web|author=Amir Alon and Alexandra Lukash|url=https://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-5071518,00.html|title=Katz, Treasury playing blame game over disability benefits delay|website=[[Ynetnews]]|date=2018-01-15|access-date=2018-06-15}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|author=Amir Alon|url=https://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-5073131,00.html|title=Katz to disabled: PM Netanyahu does not care about you|website=[[Ynetnews]]|date=2018-01-18|access-date=2018-06-18}}</ref> Fridman announced that the government was breaking the agreement and launched a campaign "We will not agree to half an Agreement".<ref>{{Cite web|author=Amir Alon|url=https://www.ynet.co.il/articles/0,7340,L-5069527,00.html|title=Disabled people launch a Campaign: Netanyahu did not stand the word|website=[[Ynet]]|language=he|publisher=Length 0:42 minutes|date=2018-01-11|access-date=2018-06-15}}</ref>
On September 12, 2018, Katz said in the government meeting that the agreement to transfer the National Insurance surplus to the Treasury is canceled. According to article 7 of the agreement, each party may notify the other party in writing, no later than three months prior to the end of a particular financial year, that from the subsequent fiscal year, it is no longer interested in investments under this agreement.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.haaretz.co.il/embeds/pdf_upload/2018/20180912-203431.pdf|title=The agreement on October 19, 1980, between the Government of Israel and the National Insurance Institute|website=[[Haaretz]]|language=he|publisher=The surpluses would be invested in Israeli governmental bonds – [[Mount Ebal|Ebal]] (5.5% per year) and [[Mount Gerizim|Gerizim]] (5% per year), which would be sold to the National Insurance Institute only|date=2018-09-12|access-date=2018-09-13}}</ref> The [[Ministry of Social Affairs and Social Services|Ministry of Labor and Social Affairs]] told the media that the situation in which the money that was supposed to guarantee the future of the allowances and of the National Insurance Institute, served the current state budget – could not continue. In a reaction, MK [[Itzik Shmuli]] said that over the years, the Finance Ministry robbed more than 220 billion ILS from the National Insurance Institute funds. Instead of keeping the money to ensure compliance with obligations, it was burned on the political needs of the governments. This reckless and dangerous behavior has led to a catastrophic situation in which the Institute would not be able to provide the elderly, disabled people and the other eligible people in the future, what they deserved by law.<ref>{{Cite web|author=Lee Yaron|url=https://www.haaretz.com/israel-news/.premium-for-first-time-since-1980-national-insurance-institute-won-t-give-surplus-to-treasury-1.6468846|title=For First Time Since 1980, Israel's Next to him, three Japanese tourists are recording the demonstration. Jerusalem, July 16, 2018.]] On January 8, 2018, Ravit Ben Baruch, a disabled leader, addressed Simhon in her video in Facebook, and told him:
''"What did you come to tell me? That as long as you could milk me with exorbitant taxes that have no parallel in any civilized country in the world, the arrangement between us worked great. Moreover, I have never earned a minimum wage, so I paid every month very good taxes, assuming naively that it was okay to cut me like it, because it went to families who needed it, but it has not been done. What can I tell you, each one of you? At the moment you would stop being a milking cow, you would have to expect it. This state would strip you of the last dignity which you still had, and would treat you as a beggar at the doorway. From the moment in which he could not suck my blood any longer, I became a burden. A burden on the state coffers. As such, he is sorry to disappoint me, I am not entitled to a pension. I get a handout and I have to thank nicely and shut up. In the sequence of the disgusting nonsense that came out of your mouth, you were right about one thing. There is no university in the world which could teach you what human compassion is. No, sir. You are just a lost cause. And do you know what? I do not need to get excited by you either. Who are you at all? You are just a pathetic little pawn, a spineless marionette which is pulled by strings. You also are not the addressee."'' <ref>{{Cite web|author=Ravit Ben Baruch|url=https://www.facebook.com/kalimi.ovadia/posts/1760786000609708|title=A monolog of Ravit Ben Baruch to the Elected Officials and to the whole Nation about the Struggle|website=[[Facebook]]|language=he|publisher=Length 10:59 minutes|date=2018-02-06|access-date=2018-07-02}}</ref>

On January 22, 2018, the "Israeli Human Rights Organization of People with Disabilities" returned and blocked the entrances to the [[Israel Aerospace Industries]],<ref>{{Cite web|author=Amir Alon and Itay Blumenthal|url=https://www.ynet.co.il/articles/0,7340,L-5074361,00.html|title=Returned to the roads: The Disabled blocked the entrance to Ben Gurion Airport|website=[[Ynet]]|language=he|publisher=Length 1:27 minutes|date=2018-01-22|access-date=2018-06-15}}</ref> and the port of Ashdod.<ref>{{Cite web|author=The Headquarters of the Struggle|url=https://www.facebook.com/matenechim/posts/10155301302662934|title=Obstacle in the Ashdod port – Disability pension at the Minimum Wage level and one beat|website=[[Facebook]]|language=he|publisher=Length 4:21 minutes|date=2018-01-22|access-date=2018-06-15}}</ref> The organization announced the government's failure to reach the outline which had been agreed in the Histadrut, and the organization's return, after painful compromises and condemnations by other Disabled, to its original demand: a disability pension of a minimum wage in one stage.
On February 12, 2018, the National Insurance Law was approved by the Labor, Welfare and Health Committee, and the disabled people also participated in the committee.<ref>{{Cite web|author=The Knesset|url=http://fs.knesset.gov.il//20/Committees/20_ptv_489763.doc|title=Protocol No. 704 From the meeting of the Labor, Welfare and Health Committee|website=[[Knesset]]|language=he|date=2018-02-12|access-date=2018-06-15}}</ref> The sums set did not meet the requirements of the disabled, but were accepted lawfully by the Knesset plenum on the night of February 12-13.<ref name=legislation /> In response, The Disabled Panthers barricaded themselves at the Knesset with other disabled people,<ref>{{Cite web|author=Amir Alon|url=https://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-5111626,00.html|title=Knesset passes bill to raise disability benefits, disabled object|website=[[Ynetnews]]|date=2018-02-13|access-date=2018-06-15}}</ref> and after an agreement with the Knesset officer, they voluntarily left the Knesset.
